  • Workplace trends

  • Join our LinkedIn community

  • Water cooler chatter
  • Question of the week

Workplace trends

Flexibility

Working from a tropical island is the new WFH

As companies and employees continue to navigate flexible work and back-to-office plans, a new type of employee has arisen: the business-leisure traveler. These digital nomads live and work abroad for longer than typical holidays without taking up permanent residence in any one place. Many resorts have branded themselves as the perfect "Work from Paradise" spots, and several islands offer "digital nomad visas" for visitors to work remotely for longer than typical tourist visas. Thousands of workers have already taken advantage of this office setup, and enthusiasm continues to grow. As a result, work-from-anywhere policies are changing, governments are trying to work out new visa and tax regulations, and businesses are focused on maintaining workplace culture across time zones and islands.

Economy

Companies are still desperate for workers

Last week's data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed 11.3 million open positions in the US in May - a sharp drop from April, but still very high by historical standards. In June, US employers added 372,000 jobs, topping bleaker expectations of 250,000. This means that for every available worker, there are nearly two job openings. Moreover, despite major high-profile job cuts, layoffs remain well below pre-pandemic levels. Several economists suggest that this indicates that the labor market, one of the main pillars of the U.S. economy, continues to remain strong, even as other economic warning signs, such as inflation and high interest rates, are raising concerns.

Employment

America's workforce is now highly self-employed

With the pandemic dramatically changing the labor market and spurring lots of Americans to adopt new workstyles, the share of the US workforce that is self-employed has climbed to its highest level since the 2008 recession. As of this past June, roughly 16.8 million people were classified as self-employed, according to recent Bloomberg calculations. This statistic reflects an increase of 1.4 million workers over the past two years, accounting for more than 33% of the total increase in the labor force in this period. As the gig economy continues to grow and flexibility shifts to a must-have for many employees, self-employed workers are on track to become even greater drivers of labor market dynamics.

Reimagining employee retention to reduce turnover

by monday.com

From trying to manage hybrid teams and return-to-office plans to navigating pandemic-induced turnover and workplace changes, it's a difficult time to be a manager.

According to recent Gartner research, the pace of annual voluntary turnover among U.S. employees is likely to jump nearly 20% this year, and it will take roughly 18% longer to fill open positions than it took before the pandemic. All this is leading managers to spend time they simply don't have searching for new recruits in a highly competitive and complicated labor market. As a consequence, managers must now focus significant efforts on employee retention in order to continue to drive performance and produce positive business impact.

The importance of career growth

In this dynamic environment, managers have been struggling to navigate the changing needs of their workers. With career growth at the forefront of many employees' minds, a perceived lack of support from their managers has led many to choose to leave their employers and grow professionally elsewhere rather than try the internal mobility route.

Why is this happening? Well, when employees excel in their roles, it's natural for a manager to prioritize their retention. The problem is that when managers are focused only on keeping the "best" people on their own teams, they fail to explore the ways in which these employees could grow elsewhere at the company. As a result, they risk compromising those team members' personal career growth opportunities and restricting their organization's access to key talent. The unfortunate outcome is that these star employees often wind up feeling constrained and eventually choose to leave in search of greater opportunities to develop elsewhere.

So, how should managers approach retention?

Help employees identify their strengths

Individuals don't always know how to spot their key strengths or understand the ways in which their skills could be developed in other roles. That's where a supportive manager can come in. Really looking out for your employees' unique attributes and helping them understand the value they bring to the table is a great way to make them feel seen and supported. Additionally, using feedback talks to not only discuss those strengths, but also to help them understand how their skills could be applied in other areas of the organization is essential to showing them their growth path within your organization.

Build connections across the company

As a manager, you typically have a wider contact pool at your organization than your employees. That's why making introductions for your team members and helping them build relationships across departments is a great way to enable them to become more familiar with the various types of roles that exist within the organization. Additionally, when individuals are encouraged to learn about other teams and departments in the company, it reduces the concern that exploring new opportunities within the organization in the future would adversely affect the way they are viewed by management.

Effectively define success

When you define successful retention as effectively maximizing your employees' potential within your organization, your approach shifts in the right direction. As a manager, striving to retain employees at the company, as opposed to strictly within your team, leads you to give your employees the tools and information they need to build a meaningful growth path within your organization. And they will be much more likely to stay and continue to contribute because of it.

Water cooler chatter

9 billion new Pokémon cards have ended the mutli-year-long shortage. Right around the Pokémon franchise's 25th anniversary, the cards saw a major resurgence in popularity, leading the company to start mass production as a way to keep up with the spike in demand. Since the Pokémon Trading Card Game launched, more than 43.2 billion cards have been produced.

"We are reprinting impacted products at maximum capacity to ensure more fans can enjoy the Pokémon TCG."

- The Pokémon Trading Card Game

Elon Musk is officially trying to pull his $44 billion offer to buy Twitter. His legal team claims this termination came about because Twitter was in material breach of their agreement and made misleading statements during negotiations.

"Mr. Musk has sought the data and information necessary to make an independent assessment of the prevalence of fake or spam accounts on Twitter's platform. Twitter has failed or refused to provide this information."

- Elon Musk's Legal Team
